णमो अरिहंताणं
णमो सिद्धाणं
णमो आयरियाणं
णमो उवज्झायाणं
णमो लोए सव्व साहूणं
एसो पंच नमोक्कारो
सव्व पावप्पणासणो
मंगलाणं च सव्वेसिं
पधमं हवई मंगलं

Explanation:

• The Navkar Mantra is the most important mantra in Jainism.
 • It pays respect to the five supreme beings: Arihants, Siddhas, Acharyas, Upadhyays, and Sadhus.
 • It is a universal prayer of peace and spiritual upliftment.
 • It's not dedicated to any one person, god, or deity.
 • It emphasizes values: purity, self-discipline, non-violence, and spiritual growth.
 • It's often the first prayer taught to every Jain child.
 • Chanting it daily brings peace, positivity, and focus on self-purification.

 Meaning Line by Line:
 1. णमो अरिहंताणं (Namo Arihantanam)
 → I bow down to the Arihants – enlightened beings who have conquered inner enemies like anger, ego, deceit, and greed.

 2. णमो सिद्धाणं (Namo Siddhanam)
 → I bow down to the Siddhas – liberated souls who have attained Moksha (liberation) and are free from the cycle of birth and death.

 3. णमो आयरियाणं (Namo Ayariyanam)
 → I bow down to the Acharyas – spiritual leaders who guide and teach others about Jain principles.

 4. णमो उवज्झायाणं (Namo Uvajjhayanam)
 → I bow down to the Upadhyays – teachers of scriptures and philosophy.

 5. णमो लोए सव्वसाहूणं (Namo Loe Savva Sahunam)
 → I bow down to all Sadhus and Sadhvis – monks and nuns who follow a path of discipline and non-violence.
